When the injunction was issued we die- continued publishing the name of the Buck's Stove and Range Company on the \"We Don't Patronize\" list of the American Federation of Labor, but editorially and upon the platform I continued to discuss the merits of the case involved and to endeavor to bring to the attention of not only the workers but of all the people the attempt by the injunction process to deny freedom of speech and liberty of the press. Frank Morrison has been sentenced to six months imprisonment, John Mitchell to nine months, and I to one year. The case is being appealed to the higher courts. Every one must agree that that is the Just and proper course to pursue; that though we hope and entertain the belief that the higher courts will reverse so flagrant an order which violates the basic principles guaranteed by the constitution of our country, we should our efforts fail in that direction we certainly must endeavor to secure relief at the hands of the lawmaking power of our country, the Congress of the United States. We shall insist that the Congress of the United States has not the power to pass a law taking the rights of free speech and free assemblage and transforming the right to so consider the laws of our country to the..     "summary": "The document discusses the issuance of an injunction that restricted the publication of Buck's Stove and Range Company by the American Federation of Labor. The author hopes the higher courts will overturn the order, which they believe violates fundamental constitutional principles.
